author: {'steamid': '76561198048776577', 'num_games_owned': 654, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1183, 'last_played': 1708830518}
review:
Some comments about the quality of the singleplayer ('offline') AI :

The AI fairly is tough, so much so that my record against the AI is actually worse than my record against human players. In real life I win about 85% of my games, against the AI here I win about 70%. 

I suspect that the reason for why the AI is pretty good is that it calculates moves based on what action will give them the highest possible gain in potential victory points from scoring regions. This works in a superficial way, so long as the AIs scoring cards come up in a timely order, and especially if the AI posseses them.

However, once you figure this out, it becomes very, very easy to outsmart the AI. I've identified a number of major issues:

1) The AI focuses far too much on preparing for upcoming scoring cards, and doesn't seem to mind even conceding Control of regions once that scoring card has been played. Since most regions are played 2-3 times per game, this sets them up for a world of hurt.

2) The AI doesn't use events enough. The AI will, about 80-90% of the time, prefer to use operations points rather than using the events. For instance, I've yet to see the AI actually use 'Containment' in the Headline Phase, even though it's a truly marvellous card from the mid-game onwards, especially if you have a weak hand.

3) The AI isn't sufficiently afraid of its opponent's events. For instance, a common AI move as the USA is to play Suez Crisis for operations points. In many situations, this is a fantastic boon to the Soviets, as they often get to remove influence from controlled Battleground states, which is effectively worth double influence, plus a sizeable points gain. There are very few situations in which any US player should ever want to play that card. Wherever possible, they should Space Race it, hold onto it, nullify it with UN Intervention, or play it at a moment when it is least effective. Yet, they almost never do this. Over the course of a whole game, the AI loses out dramatically from situations such as these.

4) The AI is obsessed with coups (in fairness, so are many human players) and will launch them at every opportunity against battleground states. The problem is, the AI doesn't seem to possess any wider understanding of how the DEFCON track affects their prospects. For instance, it often makes more strategic to try and keep the DEFCON high when you are weak, to give you more opportunities to weedle your way into non-battleground areas and eventually level the playing field. Conversely, when you are strong, it makes sense to keep the DEFCON low so the odds of a lucky coup derailing your points haul are minimal. The AI has no understanding of this. Often they will launch a long-odds coup against a battleground state in one region, and thus give themselves no hope of even getting a presence in, say, South America. The advantage to this style of play arises only when the coup-happy player gets very, very lucky from the get-go, and rolls mostly 5s and 6s for their rolls. This puts the opposing player in a bind whereby they can't counter-coup much because of the low DEFCON, and the good results limit how much of a difference they can make. Ultimately, an emphasis on coups is a low-odds strategy, not unlike playing long-ball in football. You're gonna win out spectacularly sometimes, but the majority of the time, it's going to hurt you more than it helps.

5) The AI also doesn't seem to appreciate that, over the long term, the total anount of influence you can place will often outweigh disrupting the opponent in a minor way. For instance, it makes little sense to put 2 influence into making West Germany go from 0/4 to 1/4, when you could put that 2 into Spain/Portugal, Greece, or Turkey and potentially starve the opponent of domination through sheer number of states. Worse, it can easily get trapped in a loop of performing this inefficient action, whereby every time they place enough influence to disrupt your state, you put just enough to re-secure it; meaning that the next time, they will once again have to blow an extra influence. Ultimately, the instigating player will almost always lose out in this situation. It may not matter in the short term, but in the long one, the AI will lose out on a lot of influence. In fairness, I've seen many human players fall prey to this particular vice.

6) The AI doesn't seem to understand how to wrest control of a State over the course of more than one turn. For instance, while as USA it is happy to disrupt Soviet control of, say, Italy with a spoiler play, or else seize control of it by placing a few more influence, it would *never* make the move to go from 2/4 in East Germany to 5/4, and then 7/4 the next turn. It simply can't seem to conceive of these two-step actions.

7) This leads on to by far the AIs biggest weakness: it doesn't seem to know how to claw back a region that has been locked down. When human players lose control of a region, they will usually assess whether it's worth going toe to toe for that region, or whether they can afford to lose it and make up for that loss with a more widely spread investment in other regions. e.g. it's not neccessarily such a big deal to be losing the Middle East if you can make up for it with Africa and Central America. However, the AI often concedes Control entirely in key regions such as Asia, the Middle East, and even Europe, which can appear up to 4 times a game, and are generally worth more points. Indeed...

8) The AI seems to have no idea that losing Europe is so important, and seems to only devote resources to it proportional to the points it grants. However, of course, losing Europe will lose you the game. This is made worse by the fact that the AI tends to lower the DEFCON so rapidly that realignment and coups are out of the question. When I'm the Soviets, I always play NATO every time without any fear because I know it will never even be relevant because it would be a miracle if the AI let the DEFCON stays at 5 for more than 2 seconds. This is counter to what happens when you play human players in Europe. Human players are acutely aware that losing Europe is game over, and so, barring a lucky set of Europe-centric cards, Europe typically becomes a stalemate wherein any event or influence play in Europe is met with immediate suspiscion and disproportionate sensativity. Hell, I've gotten mileage out of placing a lone influence in Europe, and spooking my opponent in order to distract them from the wider picture

As an amusing aside, the combination of low-stability battleground states and high point-scoring volatility means that the AI is obsessed with Africa, and will often spend much of the early war lovingly setting up Domination there, whilst I take France, Italy, and West Germany without it even seeming to notice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070696476', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1642790929}
review:
Обожаю настолки, но эту видимо делали люди ненавидящие СССР. Поиграв, я подумал, что видимо я крайне не везуч и мне при игре за СССР попадаются слабые карты за эту страну или куча с бонусами за США. Но просмотрев статистику других игроков онлайн, а так же детально изучив состав колоды, я понял, что ни о каком балансе тут и не пахнет (средняя статистика  65% за США и  35 % за СССР у поголовного числа игроков; бонусы при игре за США в разы мощнее бонусов за СССР; стартовое влияние в очках сразу идёт в большую сторону за США - 24 против 15 у СССР). Основная масса игроков в онлайн замесах сидят только за США, ибо зачем ухудшать рейтинг. Идиотский счетчик в 45 ДНЕЙ для ОДНОГО хода вообще убил.

НЕ покупать ни в коем случае.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970705205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 10675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1758, 'last_played': 1710702114}
review:
This game is a total gem. If you've missed out, you should try it! I highly recommend it, for a great digitalized board/card game, both in singleplayer and multiplayer. There are advanced options for difficulty, and for how the cards look and what the rules are. Game is solid, beautiful and sounds nice. The newer cards look better than in the intro video, and the pieces move faster. The AI still takes a few seconds to ponder it's move, but most other aspects seem well put together and it doesn't leave much wanting.

Functions beautifully. Beautiful graphics, good UI, no typical glitchiness or awkwardness, an artsy package, made with good taste.

Well made and functional.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003094468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2569, 'last_played': 1650286655}
review:
"Twilight Struggle" czy - jak kto woli - "Zimna Wojna" to jedna z planszówek, które najdłużej czekały na swoją elektroniczną wersję. Choć w ostatnich latach w sieci pojawiło się kilka jej internetowych odmian, to trzeba przyznać, że dopiero powyższa wersja jest tak dobrze dopracowaną. Przyjemna dla oka grafika, ciekawie oddane karty gry oraz dźwiękowy aspekt z archiwalnymi wypowiedziami i muzyką - to wszystko jest naprawdę miłym dodatkiem do wyjątkowiej rozgrywki.

Gra umożliwia tak samo grę po sieci jak i "z komputerem". Oczywiście ta pierwsza opcja daje więcej satysfakcji i emocji, ale i druga - mimo niezbyt wysokiego poziomu AI (aczkolwiek zawsze można sobie grę utrudnić poprzez handicap dla rywala) - jest miłym przerywnikiem.

Wersja cyfrowa ma też olbrzymi atut, jest o wiele prostsza w wyjaśnieniu reguł niż jej planszowy odpowiednik. To może być z pewnością sporą zachętą dla osób, dla których same przebrnięcie papierowej instrukcji było sporym wyzwaniem (polscy gracze z pewnością wiedzą o co chodzi :) ).

Grę z pełną świadomością mogę polecić. Wielbiciele planszówek znają ją od lat i ich przekonywać nie trzeba, zachęcam jednak również te osoby, które dotychczas stroniły od jej "starszego brata". Być może stanie się tak, że to właśnie elektroniczna wersja dopiero ich zachęci do zakupu pudełka. Polecam!

Sama w sobie gra jest absolutnie niepowtarzalna z każdą kolejną rozgrywką, każde pdoejście do niej jest inne, zawsze (w zależności od gry przeciwnika oraz wylosowanych kart) trzeba inaczej podchodzić do zwycięstwa. I choć to "zimna wojna", to emocje przy niej mogą być gorące. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198119744508', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1708691789}
review: A gorgeous adaptation of the greatest board game of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970545713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1531, 'last_played': 1478328796}
review: Twilight Struggle is one of the longest Top 10 Board Games on BoardGameGeek.com for good reasons.  It offers deep, strategic choices with a compelling historical theme.  This PC adaptation allows the computer to keep track of all the rules and placement so you can focus intently on your struggle to expand your world influence, while avoiding a nuclear war.  Or teaches that crushing your opponent so badly risks their starting a nuclear war just to deny you the victory.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994896594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1641774817}
review: Simple rules, deep as an ocean.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970743816', 'num_games_owned': 1748, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 18173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 142, 'playtime_at_review': 15156, 'last_played': 1712423536}
review:
Outstanding digital port of an incredible bit of game design. I learned Twilight Struggle several years ago, and had a few face to face matches at the time. I liked the game, but when investing blocks of time into face-to-face physical boardgaming I tend to want to move onto new experiences. 

This digital port of Twilight Stuggle allowed me to explore the game design space of this seminal design, and play many players at and above my level of skill. 

There are a few minor quibbles -- choosing which side you are bidding for when bidding for sides is particularly unclear. But overall it's a great port, and it's particularly great that it interfaces seemlessly with the mobile tablet versions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198310952000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 21096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2776, 'last_played': 1702434423}
review: This is a great software treatment of a favorite board game. Online matches are good too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028313452', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 62130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 141, 'playtime_at_review': 24371, 'last_played': 1712364908}
review:
The digital implementation of Twilight Struggle is faithful to the award winning board game.  Twilight Struggle is easily one of the best strategic games of all time.  Two players are constantly attempting to out-think each other while figuring out how best to play the hand they are dealt. If you have the analog version and cannot find opponents, this is the game for you.

Set during the cold war, the game is a card driven battle for ideological world supremacy.  The goal is to gain victory points by dominating the various regions in the world by having the most influence there.

There are 3 ways to win:
1) have the edge in Victory Points at the end of 10 turns;
2) achieve an automatic victory by gaining 20 Victory Points
3) if the other player goes to DEFCON 1.

The key to playing this game well is the cards.  Playing your hand to your best advantage, or often, to the least detriment.  If you canget rid of the opposing players cards with the least amount of damage to your position you will do well.  In order to do that, you have to play, and learn.  The most dangerous cards to you are often the weakest in your opponents hand.

Play early, play often and enjoy every game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004270644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1461470839}
review: Nice conversion of a tabletop board game to video game. Just like the physical board game, your experience depends on the knowledge of the cards that are potentially in play in each war era (early, mid, and late). This makes the game become easier as the number of games played increase. The game can help educate you in a number of events that helped shape the course of the Cold War era, but it is not a simulation of those events.

review: Seems to be a fairly well done port with some nice touches like historic speeches playing when you pull up a card. Being fairly familiar with the board game it's easy to get the hang of this. I would only suggest that you make sure a friend has the game as well cause the AI is laughably bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960334347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1232, 'last_played': 1519874576}
review:
A faithful reproduction of one of the most highly rated board games.  The board game was the #1 board game on boardgamegeek for a long time.
A 2-player strategy game, full of suspense, and requiring only a limited amount of luck, masterful decision-making and foresight is the key to achieving dominance.
A few bugs still lurk in the game at this time, and the AI is only challenging for new players and to learn the game (I have beaten it every time I play).  Find a friend, or play online, and be prepared for some mental torture as you try to gain the upper-hand and avoid a catastrophic DEFCON suicide!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995476665', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1511646651}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014197372', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 44837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 322, 'playtime_at_review': 873, 'last_played': 1712217919}
review: Dopo una lunghissima permanenza al vertice delle più importanti classifiche dei boardgame finalmente una versione da pc da poter giocare con un avversario online o anche in singolo contro il computer. L'intelligenza artificiale è davvero molto abile, ai limiti della legalità, e renderà ogni partita una dura sfida. Consigliatissimo sia per il background, dettagliato e ricercatissimo, sul quale il gioco si basa sia per la meccanica in se. Un must.

review: Un juego de tablero pasado de forma magistral al ordenador. author: {'steamid': '76561198001879133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 32434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8859, 'last_played': 1703104670}
review:
Twilight Struggle es la adaptación del juego de tablero. 
La adaptación es bastante buena y la interfaz tiene poco margen de mejora. En general es bastante cómodo poder jugar en ella. Yo implantaría un rollback del turno que el rival pudiera aceptar o no. De esa forma se evitarían algunas bajadas de defcon que he visto por error.

El único punto negativo es la IA que deja bastante que desear. Por lo demás, ideal para poder jugar a uno de los mejores juegos de tablero.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960291302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 9388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6583, 'last_played': 1686331505}
review:
I love boardgames, but let's be honest, memorizing the rules and setting up the pieces takes forever.

Pros:
- Card & map graphics are crisp and clear.
- Nice Cold War ambience w/ scattered clips of famous speeches and other period sound effects.
- Multiplayer games, of varying lengths (PBEM included), are easy to setup.
- Tutorial is decent at explaining fairly complex rules and strategy.
- A great facsimile of the original tabletop game.

Cons:
- The AI is often terrible; it finds ways to ineptly lose games by triggering DEFCON 1 all on their own. I've never finished a game via final scoring after HUNDREDS of attempts.
- UI is a little clunky.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990985601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 8651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2212, 'last_played': 1617216209}

review: Fiel ao jogo de tabuleiro. Inteface intuitiva, muito boa. Raramente acontece algum tipo de "miss click". Permite jogar partidas rápidas (45min ou 90min) e longas (3 ou 7 dias). Obrigatório a qualquer 1 que goste de 10+ jogos ( pq qm gosta de menos nem eh gamer entao n conta kkkkk). Um jogo de tabuleiro que ja ta no meu top5 de jogos mais jogados da vida.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989174362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 910, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1707402513}
review:
I really really like this game. It's one of those few good PC games that makes you want to leave yuor house for the unpleasent outside world and buy the boardgame. Or, if that's to much for you..  just order it online and have it delivered. Anyway the PC & the Board game are both great. The PC game is vs human or AI.

So what is it? Well Twilight Struggle is a strategic two-player boardgame set during the Cold War. The USA and the Soviet Union struggle to control various key countries in the world. The game mechanics are card driven with some dice rolling and hand management.

Their is a bit of a learning curve at the start, especially if you have not played this kind of game before. However, once you have got a couple of games under your belt it becomes a joy to play. 

I can highly recomend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042937568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1523079600}
review:
Excellent adaptation of the board game.  Having grown up in the Cold War, working for the US Air Force (civilian), and remembering many of these events from the daily newspaper, I am particularly fond of this game.  The experience of historical events playing out across the world is what makes this game appealing and winning the game is almost an afterthought.  Because I have played the board game several times prior to this purchase, I skipped the tutorial and have no opinion on it.  This game is very different, complex, and the options are not intuitive, so without a copy of the boardgame rules for reference, you may "struggle" a bit at first, even having played the boardgame before.  But the game interface is good and you can preview card results before committing, including probability of successful die rolls and region scoring.  This avoids the bookkeeping/chart consulting issues of the boardgame, so computer play is really easier.  Now I need to get my out of town gaming friends to get copies for on line play.    

Only played twice so far (losing both) and yes, it is hard to survive as the US in the early game, just as it is in the original board game.  The random factor is significant and you may get stuck with cards that make winning impossible.  US goal is to hang in there and not go down too many points before Mid and Late War cards come in to play, swinging events in US favor.  DONT LOSE WESTERN EUROPE!  Send the harshest Soviet event cards to the Space Race in the early game.  Computer play is no different than strategy in the boardgame.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973899044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 2055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1368, 'last_played': 1564465153}
review:
Vorab: bin heute an einem Sonntag extra zur Tanke gefahren, um mir Guthaben zu besorgen, als ich dieses Spiel entdeckt habe und ich wurde nicht entäuscht.

Ich will hier jetzt nicht das ganze Spiel erklären, das haben schon andere getan. Ich kann nur sagen: wenn du Rundenstrategie magst und Interesse am kalten Krieg hast, dann ist das für dich ein Pflichtkauf!

Das physische Brettspiel dazu habe ich noch nicht gespielt aber es scheint so, dass es hier 1zu1 in einem Videospiel umgewandelt wurde. Der einzige Unterschied: man muss die Punkte nicht selber zählen :)

Habe jetzt 5 Stunden durchgespielt. Und ja, nach den 5 Stunden kenne ich die meisten Karten schon, aber das Spiel ist immer anders!!!

Die KI ist sehr gut! Sie arbeitet bei jedem Zug ein paar Sekunden, aber das ist gar nicht schlimm, da sie dann gute Züge macht und es sich so anfühlt, als ob ein Mensch vor dir sitzt (dieser muss natürlich auch überlegen ;) ).
Es gibt kein Zeitlimit im Singleplayer. Und manchmal ist das auch gut so, da man schon sehr gut planen muss, was man in den nächsten 3, 4 Zügen macht.

Insgesamt: SUPER! :)

Für 8 Euro im Sale auf jeden Fall kaufen. Beim Normalpreis von 15 Euro muss es jeder selbst entscheiden ( bei 8 Euro natürlich auch ;) ). Das Brettspiel selber kostet ca. 40 Dollar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013915811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1710472113}
review: This is a very well done game. One of the best board game to video game adaptations I have ever seen. Very clean UI and intuitive controls. Even the sound effects and music are amazing. I recommend watching some videos to learn how to play because this game is not easy. Once you get the hang of it then you will have lots of fun.

review:
This is a fun game. Friend got me hooked on it. I don't know how it plays otherwise as I generally only play with a friend but it's been entertaining every time we played. I was a political science major history minor in unversity so for me it was fun since I knew most of the event cards and such. I don't know if everybody will get that same kind of enjoyment. 

That being said, the mechanics of the game are still solid and I think it's worth trying out regardless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101463187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1508365972}

author: {'steamid': '76561198155250630', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1706116050}

author: {'steamid': '76561198066162839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 1506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1233, 'last_played': 1556170590}
review:
I highly recommend anyone interested in this game to watch a few youtube videos/reviews of the board game to get a feel for it first. For me this is hands down the best board game of all time but not everyone will agree with that assessment. The digital version is pretty decent. If you've played any digital board games on Steam you've likely experienced some bugs or UI issues. I haven't noticed any bugs but the UI will take a bit to adjust to. Overall the UI isn't as bad as many other digital board games I've played but I can't say any of them have been perfect.

This is not a simple game to grasp. I struggled (heh) with it for several days before I decided to read some basic strategy tips and learned from my mistakes. But now that I have the basics down I find playing both sides interesting and challenging in their own ways. The two sides are pretty well balanced but the USSR will probably feel more powerful to a new player. The game is designed for the USSR player to initiate the conflict while the USA player reacts and counter-plays. It is for that reason I highly recommend you play as the USA until you understand the basics and can beat the AI.

If you enjoy challenging strategy games and have an interest in the Cold War this is one of the best games on Steam for you.

10/10 Board Game
8/10 Digital Version

author: {'steamid': '76561197964474618', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1617037311}
review:
『冷戰熱鬥』的電子版桌遊
　　相較於實體版遊戲，電子版一直以來都有著不用SET TOKEN和作細部計算等等的優點，但是這都沒有比幫你紀錄計分卡來的重要！現在你終於不用一直耗費腦中記憶體去記牌，因為ＵＩ介面會非常好心的告訴你，在下次洗牌前哪些計分卡已經使用過了，還有你可以直接點開區域的介面了解自己的區域分數，以及在按下確定前都還有反悔機會的回溯按鈕，都是在幫助我們這些手腦殘老馬的貼心設計。


　　『冷戰熱鬥』本身就是一個非常有時代帶入感的作品，但是電子版並沒有馬虎，他們取材了不少當年的廣播音效，你可以在裡面聽到每個回合的代表人物廣播，也會聽到甘迺迪總統那句傳奇名言，彷彿你打出來的事件真的在這個世界線中發生，不再是一個很單純的卡牌。


　　方便的ＵＩ和廣播音效是最讓人大推的地方，只可惜還沒有中文化這點是個大硬傷。

author: {'steamid': '76561198002170172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1506729216}
review:
Hallo ihr Brettspieler da draußen :)

Obwohl ich bis jetzt nur das Tutorial gespielt hab & mir 4 Youtube Lets plays angesehen habe bin ich überzeugt das ich dieses Spiel von nun an öfters spielen werde. 
Die Game-mechanik ist rundenbasiert und man zieht Karten mit deren Hilfe man Einfluß in Ländern gewinnen kann (Was der Gegner natürlich auch kann). 
Aber indem man die Karten per Drag & Drop zum ausspielen nach obenzieht muß man, dadurch in welchem "Slot" man sie ablegt, auswählen für was sie verwendet werden sollen. Denn Einfluß in Ländern direkt zu verändern ist nur eine von vielen Möglichkeiten. So kann man Beispielsweise auch einen Coup herbeiführen - was so eine Art Handstreich ist - damit kann man auch in Ländern Einfluß umverteilen in denen der Gegner schon agiert hat ; zu denen man selber aber bis lang keinen Zugang hatte (weil man kein angrenztes Land besitzt) - Diese Aktion wird dann ausgewürfelt. 
Es gibt noch weitere vielfältige Möglichkeiten den Spielhergang zu verändern. Die Grundregeln des Spiels erschließen sich schnell. ABER dadurch ist man noch lang kein erprobter Taktikexperte. Im Internet kann man sehr detailierte Seiten zu Strategien finden. 

Auch wenn es bestimmt noch ein bißchen dauert bis ich in-game nicht irgendwelche wichtigen Sachen außer acht lasse & die richtigen Entscheidungen treffe habe ich jetzt schon sehr viel Freude an dieser Softwareperle. Die Atmosphäre ist toll & einfach genial. 

Ich kann für Brettspiel- & Kalter-Krieg-Liebhaber dieses Game einfach nur ganz klar empfehlen. 
Danke für´s Lesen & viel Spaß beim Umschreiben der Geschichte wünsche ich Euch !

EDIT: 
Einige Achievements funktionieren nicht/ Die DEVs wurden schon mehrere Male darauf hingewiesen - passiert ist alleredings nichts.

review: What bothers me, that you're not able to see the whole world map at once. the info at the top and the card hand at the bottom take up to much space, and the writing is to big. i want an option to optimize my layout. almost half of south-america and south-africa are almost constantly covered, and you need several klicks to see the situation there. this is really a game breaker, and not just some small issue. i will continue to use the vassal module instead of this pc implementation, unless this gets fixed. add an option to zoom the map further out - easy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990152351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 97984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19461, 'last_played': 1691852172}
review:
This is one of the finest board games ever conceived.  Although the board game came out in 2004, this electronic version released in 2016 offers much greater convenience over its physical predecessor.  Intense, hair-raising gameplay with Incredible replayability, and an outstanding multiplayer experience (built-in chat interface, ELO rankings, friends list)

Twilight Struggle should be required playing for anyone feeling overly nostalgic for the Cold War.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036976146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1598637480}
review:
I'll make it short.

Loved the board game from the get go and it had rightfull place in no 1 for a long time on boardgamegeek and is my fav 2 player game. Saddly in a week since buying digital version I have not see one game online to join or anyone joining my, so not sure how is that supposed to work unless you have friends to play with.

I have not enabled DLC as reviews suggest its not working correctly, but base game works very well and streamlines matches cutting the time considerably if you know the game already.

AI is quite poor for even intermediate players, so its probably just geared towards beginners.

In general if you have someone to play online buy it, otherwise better get a board version and play with someone in your living room.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972462277', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1626, 'last_played': 1499126657}
review:
It's a thumbs up, the game is a good port of the board game.

My biggest complaint is the AI, even after all this time, it just does really stupid things. For example, the Sadat card kicks Russian out of Egypt and gives the US an influence. The AI used it as a 1 point influence placement, while leaving my 3-1 Russian lead in Egypt alone. Played as the event, it'd have been a 4 point influence point swing.

Now, I get sometimes that 1 point in one place is worth giving up more points elsewhere, but this wasn't one of them, it wasn't even close. I don't expect an AI to be fantastic in an indie game, but this is an easy calculation (events vs ops points) and the AI does them poorly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000493031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1544645675}
review:
Twilight Struggle:- Git Gud Comrade!

I downloaded this after a friend got me 'Twilight Struggle' as a board game, and after finding a dearth of people to play against in my home town, I picked up this version during the Summer Sale. While I do reccommend it, I have a number of caveats listed below.

1) Victory or loss in the Tabletop version of this game is heavily dependent on Luck, and that carries over to this version. However, when you play against the AI, the way in which dice rolls are presented is very 'tell don't show', and when combined with the way in which they seem to come out , it makes it appear that the AI is manipulating the rolls. Whether or not it is, I don't feel qualified to say. 

2) The same goes for cards: The AI is uncannily good at predicting your cards and what you're going to do with them. This could be down to good programming, but if that is the case then there  should be levels of AI for duffers to play against (think Carter, Kennedy, Reagan levels of opponent). Don't pick this version up and expect it to teach you the game: playing against the AI looking to improve is like asking for tips on a Dark Souls Forum.

3) Once you're playing against a fellow human, some of the cards are difficult to use. E.G. Destalinisation (in the game, this is take 4 influence and move it somewhere  else) if you mislay one piece of influence, the only recourse is the 'undo' button, which takes you right back to the start of the process, which can often take quite a while: something punishing for new players up against the clock.

4) As a colourblind dude, some of the regions can be quite muddy. One of my recent defeats was because I undertook a Coup in a country, mistaing the region it was in, as it was on the frontier of 2. There should be an ability to find out exactly which regions countries are in (possibly an info box). Likewise, there should be a  Window/Menu for seeing the state of the world in precis. Several cards seem to be based on who has the most regions/ battlegrounds in the world, and an ability to see this immediately would be nice.

Beyond that, its more-or-less the same as the board game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064259012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1593469152}
review:
An excellent conversion of the board game - you can relive the perils and pitfalls, triumphs and tragedies of the cold war as either the USA or USSR, striving to increase your influence at the expense of your opponent and deploying your assets to make or break the game.

It's a turn based strategy with a fairly orthodox playing structure - each player makes their moves; action and counter-action between the two sides and every now and then, you get to drop in a whammy that can change overall strategy.  It's half planning, half reacting to your opponent's choices which makes for a good variety.

Overall gameplay on the PC takes about 90 minutes to get through a game (if you know what you're doing) and the PC's AI is pretty good although is known to make a few obvious blunders.  Worth parting with your cash, even if you have the board game version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010539641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1512, 'last_played': 1643389218}
review:
Twilight Struggle is one of the best board games ever made.  I make that statement not off of opinion but one supported by facts via aggregated statistics.  See: BoardGameGeek, where this game reigned #1 and is only recently dethroned by flavor of the month games well after a decade of it's reign.  The digital implementation is joyous; I've seen no bugs.  If you're a new player, you may think there are bugs but pay close attention to card verbiage and the tutorial.  If you just lost and you don't understand how it's probably because you were the phasing player while the defcon track moved to thremonuclear war.  Hint: Don't be that guy.

Why is this game different?
There are 3 types of cards you're dealt.  Your cards, your opponents cards, and neutral cards.  For neutral cards and your cards you have a decision to make.  You will choose to EITHER do what the card SAYS OR spend the numeric value of the card to perform 1 of 3 diffecent actions.  Your opponents cards, when you play them...this is the real !@#$%...what the card says...IT DOES.  Period, no way around it (you can mitigate the impact of the card(s) thru smart play).  This is a two player game.  Not 3.  The AI is decent but it cheats a bit.  Online play is good.

The general mood of the game is well done, with the very occasional sound bit upping the tension of this mental slough.   

If you think you might like this and you're up to the task of learning the rules (there is a great tutorial) then buy this game, you won't regret it.  

Further mechanics/rules discussion-

Card Values, 1 -4, not to be increased beyond 4 or reduced below 1.

DEFCON track indicates the required number of military operations points you need.  Improving this means it will move closer to 5, degrading means closer to thermonuclear war.  As this moves it will increasingly limit your ability to interact with your opponents influence on the board.

There are ten Turns in which you play out typically either 6 or 7 cards from your hand.  Each card play is an action round.  

There are technically five different things that you can use cards for, see below--

Military realignments: 
Which is the tradiitonal Risk's "My die vs your die."  This tend to become more of thing towards the end of the game.  These are MODIFIED with pluses based off of several factors, if you control a country that's next to the country that's being realigned, +1 (works both ways and for as many countries as applicable.  +1 for the country next to the superpower (US or USSR). +1 for having more influence than your opponent in the country that's being realigned. 

Space Race:
If you meet the varying prerequistes, you may discard a card, typically, once per turn. (You'll almost always do this with your opponents MOST crippling card)

Place Influnce:
This is how you "put your army" into the battlespace.  Typically, this is a 1 for 1 investment, if you choose to "Place Influnece" using a card with a value of 3, you get to place 3 influence. Remember we're talking about the cold war thou, so you're actually just flexing your polical might.  Influence is how you take control of contries.  If you opponent already controls the country (you need to have X MORE than a the number annotated on the country for controll) then it will cost you 2 points to place 1 influence.  There are more details to this but I won't continue to discuss them.

Conduct a Coup:
Attack a country removing and potentially replacing your opponents influence in a country. Coups modify the afforementioned DEFCON track when their targets are certain countries.  How does a COUP work?  Remember that number on every country that you must have MORE of then you opponent to control it.  That's effectively it's defense for the purpose of coups.  Take Iran for example, you must have 2 MORE than your opponent in influence to control the country, with coups you double that number which now becomes 4.  I use a 4 value card to coup Iran.  I've already met the requirement for the coup to be successful...now it's a matter of how much of my opponents influnce I'm taking away.  Lets say there is 4 of my opponents influence in that country.  I will subtract an influence based off my die roll, I roll a 5. 4 - 5 = -1 So I would completely remove all 4 of my opponents influence and add 1 of my own.  Coups are your primary method of obtaining required military operations.  That's coups in a nutshell.

The above 4 choices you're performing based off of the numerical value on the card (to include space race to an extent), below is not so.

Play the Event: 
What the card says happens, happens.  Sometimes the card will enable you to do things you could not otherwise do, like place 1 influence into a country you cannot access or your opponent controls.  Just rtfc.  NOW, recall earlier I said if you're playing your opponents card, the event happens, period (there is one card in the game that prevents this).  You're still presented with a choice when playing an opponents card, you can either have the event resolve before OR after you've used the card for it's operations value (the number on the card).  Always being able to make this decision helps you mitigate the impact of playing something your opponent will, most of the time, benefit from.

Yes, the rules ar daunting, but a more satisfying board game you'll be hard pressed to find once you've learned how to play.  

I'm an amatuer and have only been playing a few months.  Play USSR if you're new.  The typical online game will bid for sides with the USSR taking a slight handcap for the superior early game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037045781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1001, 'last_played': 1560028008}
review:
It's Twilight Struggle online.

If you haven't played the board game, I don't think I'd recommend this until you try it. It's a board game for a very particular audience, and given that this is just a straight-up digital version of that game, you won't like this if you don't like the board game. The rest of my review will assume you're already familiar with the game.

I'm also going to include a review of the DLC in here because I think it's one of the biggest incentives to pick up this version if you're interested, and therefore if you aren't interested in any of it that's something worth keeping in mind.

--

I think this is about as faithful of an adaptation of TS as you're likely to get. The rules are all there, and you'll likely even learn a few things you didn't know about the rules, or at least how playdek interprets them, in edge cases.

The implementation of the base game itself is about as faithful as is possible. There are a few interface oversights which are to some extent inevitable when porting this to a computer, such as the fact that there's no confirmation request for headline events and in general the ability to 'take back' cards is somewhat inconsistent in my experience (for example, I don't see any downside to being able to take back an opponent event I put down if the opponent hasn't actually made any decisions yet). However, after a game or two getting used to the interface it'll feel pretty natural.

The AI is pretty awful and more or less just makes random decisions, but I don't think any of us really intended to play against it anyways. It might be good for showing the mechanics to new players but you'll want to go online as soon as possible.

DLC comments follow:

Turn Zero and the alternative Space Race track are both here from the collectors' edition, for those of us who didn't snag a copy in the kickstarter. Honestly, I'm not a fan of either. Turn Zero is highly random and tends to be imbalanced enough that you know who's likely to win the game before the first turn, which can be demoralizing and make you question whether it's worth playing everything else out. The Space Race track changes the game dynamic in a very strange way, turning the Space Race track from something which largely exists as a black hole for bad events into a very powerful track: in particular, calling Eagle/Bear has Landed 'comically overpowered' is the understatement of the century. I don't think I like this, given how random advancement on the track can be.

On the other hand, the promo cards they added are very solid. The chance of unavoidable defcon suicide has gone from "almost nothing" to "slighty more than almost nothing" due to the addition of two more suicide cards, but all in all the new events are fun and I think they help balance the game somewhat. I'm not a huge fan of the fan-made solution to balance problems in the base game being giving the US extra influence at the game start since it leads to some goofy situations, such as a turn 1 middle east scoring headline for the US being a huge VP swing due to nothing but luck, so this is a very nice alternative. The one problem is if you play with optional cards as well (which you probably want to, since they're also good as anyone who plays TS knows) you will likely not have a turn 7 reshuffle, which has a massive effect on how the game plays out. It would be nice to see some sort of deckbuilding feature: I don't think anyone would miss Summit too much, for example.

First Lightning is very poorly worded and will take you one or two tries to get the hang of, but given how many gotchyas there are in the base game this should be par for the course for veterans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016627844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 7690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2890, 'last_played': 1634520982}
review: Twilight Struggle is a faithful digital recreation of the famous tabletop geopolitical strategy game.  Fans of the board game will doubtless be satisfied with it.  For newcomers, it offers a dynamic and engaging look at the Cold War.  Players square off as either the U.S. or U.S.S.R. and try to navigate the Cold War from the aftermath of the Second World War through the 1980s.  Each turn is carried out by the players using cards to drive historical events and operations, such as coups, political realignments, and advancing the space race.  The goal is to spread your influence around the globe, while stifling your opponent's attempts to do the same.  Both the card-driven nature of the game and the variety of nations on the game-board ensure there are near infinite possibilities available in striving for global dominance.  The random nature of the scoring cards also allows for players to try and bluff one another in where and how they extend their influence.  I would highly recommend this game to anyone who desires an immersive and engaging strategy game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999237085', 'num_games_owned': 933, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1532243712}
review:
I can see why the cardboard version of this spent many years at the top of the boardgamegeek lists. The mechanics of this game are impeccable. This pc conversion and the tablet version are very nice translations  of the classic game, and recommended to anyone fond of 1v1 area control or hand management games. 

Twilight struggle may initially appear to be a wargame, but is very different to traditional wargames in that there are no troops and it it predominantly about influence management and intrigue. Your hand consists of cards based on cold-war events which can be payed for map control points or historical effects, and many of the cards you play will have positive effects for your opponent regardless. As such you are playing against your own hand as much as your foe. It creates an awkward tug of war between provocation and damage control, evocative of a political era characterized by superpowers pushing each other to the brink of nuclear annihilation in a struggle for dominance. 

It is this vibe that makes it truly great, and I think gives it much wider appeal than even related classics like Risk and Diplomacy. It is a bit "euro" though, which may be intimidating in a cardboard version for the uninitiated, but this pc version has nailed the quality of life and help systems to ease learning. 

So if you like board games, political games such as Paradox Studio titles, or want to try a wargame of a very different style, give it a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026457867', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1654473316}
review:
I have loved this as a board game for a long time. The problem there is very few of my game groups like these kinds of games (or are setup for two players.) So this version is amazing and helps me scratch that "Gotta play a game" itch when I can't round up any friends.

If you have ever seen the board game and have been interested, this is a great way to learn the mechanics and try and develop strategies. 

Highly recommended if you love board games, deep strategy games, or want to lose yourself for an hour or two in the depths of communist paranoia :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197962082784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 493, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1495157634}
review:
Good implementation of a heavy board game. In fact, all my problems with this stem more or less from the board game half of the equation.

First, there is vs AI and online play, using Playdek's very good crossplay online implementation. If you have played their mobile board games, you know it, otherwise, the games have a varying play clock from 45 minutes to 45 days per player which ticks down when it is your turn and only then, so you could have a match you hash out then and there or a match you play over months.

The AI will kill you if you are new at the game but if you start getting a handle on the game and start finding its inexplicable weaknesses, you will surely destroy it. Any half-decent Cold Warrior will very quickly start outmaneuvering it and watching the AI not even put up a token fight in regions it REALLY SHOULD be trying to muscle you out of.

For the actual boardgame, Twilight Struggle is a dense, yet surprisingly simple, board game themed around the Cold War. As either USA or USSR, you jockey for control over the map, your usual actions being just placing influence tokens in countries or rolling dice to beat back enemy influence tokens. The brilliance, and flaws, of this system, come from the deck that decides your actions. Each card is a number, which is your "Ops" or action points, and also a historical event that benefits USA or USSR. If you play the opposite team's card, they get the event, you get the points. If you play your team's card, you only get event or points, not both. Since you're both drawing from the same deck, you are often looking at a bunch of bad options to try to mitigate enemy advantage or play yours at the best opportunity.

This deck ALSO spits out scoring cards, a card that scores VP in a region of the map based on who controls it, so you do not quite know when a certain region will be scored and thus over the course of the game you will be advancing, feinting, and retreating to try squeeze out control of the regions when you think (Or are holding and thus know) their scoring card is coming.

This, and many other things, create great Cold War style tension. My issue is that so much of the game revolves around that deck memorization. Both sides must strategize around cards that have yet to come from the deck, so getting a feel for which countries are likely to be flipped by event cards is mandatory before you can even begin to see where the actual depth of this game is. This also puts the strategy of TS solely on understanding the TS deck and not so much on a more general strategy. The greatest board gamer in the world who has only one learning game of TS under his belt is likely to get destroyed by someone who has played the game 20 times and is not all THAT good. It is a very peculiar game and most of the strategy involved is peculiar and specific to TS and TS alone, and at times feels like it is a game that can really only appeal to its own fans. That said, it is certainly an interesting board game and worth picking up for anyone curious to see how this sat at #1 at Boardgamegeek (Normally notorious for their garbage taste in board games) for so long.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2563, 'playtime_forever': 861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1558751365}
review:
Zum 400. Review gibts eine echte Perle:

"Twilight Struggle" ist die (englischsprachige) digitale Umsetzung eines herausragenden Brettspiels, das in der deutschen Version "Gleichgewicht des Schreckens" hieß.

Der kalte Krieg. Eine hochspannende und hochgefährliche Ära. Zwei Supermächte, die USA und die UdSSR versuchten weltweit ihren Einfluß zu erhöhen. Zwei Systeme stritten miteinander. Mit diplomatischen, geheimdienstlichen und militärischen Mitteln. Stellvertreterkriege wurden vom Zaun gebrochen. Viele Ereignisse machten deutlich wie nah die Welt am Abgrund, am alles vernichtenden Atomkrieg stand, ob Kuba Krise oder Korea Krieg. "Twilight Struggle" versucht diese in einem komplexen kartenbasierten Brettspiel deutlich und spielbar zu machen. Und das gelingt meisterlich und mit grandiosem Erfolg.

"Twilight Struggle" ist für zwei Spieler ausgelegt. Einer spielt die USA, der andere übernimmt die UdSSR. In dieser digitalen Variante des Karten-Brettspiels können wir entweder gegen die KI antreten - die meist ganz erstaunlich clever agiert, Schwächen erkennt und auch einige Züge im Voraus zu denken vermag - oder online gegen einen menschlichen Gegner. Dabei gibt es ein Zeitlimit, das wie eine Schachuhr funktioniert, also nur bei dem läuft, der auch am Zuge ist. Eine normal laufende Partie dauert in der Regel (wenn sie nicht früh abrupt durch die atomare Katastrophe endet, was durch unvorsichtiges Agieren schnell passieren kann) in etwa eine Stunde, plus minus je nach Kontrahentenkonstellation.

Das Spiel ist aufgeteilt in drei große Phasen, die Zeitabschnitte repräsentieren. Beginnt ein neuer Abschnitt kommen neue Karten hinzu. Bestimmte Karten werden immer wieder ins Deck gemischt. Andere werden nach einmaligem Ausspielen aus dem Spiel entfernt. Die drei großen Phasen sind dann nochmal in eine bestimmte Anzahl Runden aufgeteilt (3-4-3). In jeder Runde werden eine bestimmte Anzahl Karten ausgespielt (6-8). Eine kleine Anzahl Karten kann gehalten werden und wird in die nächste Runde mitgenommen.

Die Karten haben mehrere Informationen. Zum Einen ein Event, das beschrieben wird und dessen Auswirkungen in Kraft treten, wenn wir die Karte als Event ausspielen. Auf der Karte ist auch eine Ziffer, die die Stärke der Karte repräsentiert. Wir können auch diese Punkte einsetzen, um Einfluß in Ländern zu erzielen. Jedes Land hat einen bestimmten Wert. Erreicht die Differenz zwischen den Einflußpunkten der beiden Spieler in dem Land diesen Wert, hat der jeweilige Spieler unter Kontrolle und es wird schwerer für den Gegner hier Einfluß zu platzieren. Die Kartenpunkte können auch eingesetzt werden um einen Coup in einem Land zu machen. Um zu ermitteln, ob der Coup erfolgreich ist, wird die Stärke des Landes, die schon existierenden Einflußpunkte und ein Würfelwurf einberechnet. Ein gelungener Coup setzt allerdings den DEFCON Level (1-5) runter. Bei DEFCON 1 kommt es zur atomaren Katastrophe und das Spiel endet sofort.

Ungeliebte Karten (in der Regel Karten, die ein starkes gegnerisches Event triggern) können auch im Space Race eingesetzt werden, durch das man auch Punkte bekommen kann.

Alle der hochintelligent aufeinander abgestimmten Mechaniken können hier gar nicht erwähnt werden. Headline-Phase (bei der ersten ausgespielten Karte einer Runde wird immer das Event ausgelöst) oder China-Karte, die wenn sie ausgespielt wird in der nächsten Runde dem Gegner zur Verfügung steht.

Gewonnen hat eine Seite, wenn die Differenz an Victory-Points 20 erreicht. Victory-Points erreicht man durch vieles, durch Space-Race, Karten-Events aber auch durch Scoring-Cards, die, wenn ausgespielt den momentanen Einflußstand in einer Weltregion bewerten. 

Ich könnte noch weitaus mehr ins Detail gehen. Es ist komplex, trotzdem man eigentlich meist nur Karten ausspielt. Es ist, und das ist das wichtigste, eine unglaublich gute, unglaublich intelligente, unglaublich durchdachte, historisch akkurate Repräsentation einer bewegten Ära. Soviel historisches Feingefühl findet sich extrem selten. Die eigentlich simple Grundlage eines kartenbasierten Spiels wird durch das Regelwerk zu einer Erfahrung, die es notwendig macht über jeden Zug gründlich nachzudenken. Die Frage wann man eine Karte ausspielt ist extrem wichtig und entscheidend. Daß fast alle Karten als unterschiedliche Aktion ausgespielt werden können (Event, Einfluß, Coup, Space Race, Realignement) erhöht die Komplexität enorm.

Daß das Zeitlimit online wie eine Schachuhr funktioniert ist kein Zufall. Auch wenn die Mechaniken ganz andere sind, wird man ähnlich wie beim Schach dazu geleitet, komplex und mehrere Züge im Voraus zu denken. Zudem muß man auch dringend den Gegner analysieren und sollte durch dessen Handlungen versuchen einzuschätzen, welche Karten er vielleicht noch auf der Hand hat. Man selber darf sich allerdings auch nicht durch seine Aktionen zu sehr verraten, sonst kann der Gegner gezielt reagieren. Das Spiel wird zudem immer komplexer, da im Verlauf der Phasen tendenziell immer mehr Karten hinzukommen.   

Hat man zum Beispiel die Karte "Asia Scoring" auf der Hand, wird man versuchen sie am Ende der Runde auszuspielen und innerhalb der Runde den Einfluß in Asien so weit wie möglich zu steigern, um dann durch die Scoring-Karte möglichst viele Victory-Points zu bekommen. Setzen wir aber gleich zu Beginn alles in Asien ein, wird unser Gegner diese Taktik erkennen und Gegenmaßnahmen versuchen, etwa Coups in Asien machen. Da die Scoring-Karten in der jeweiligen Runde ausgespielt werden müssen, kann dies dazu führen, daß wir unserem Gegner Victory Points schenken, weil er uns zu früh einschätzen konnte.

"Twilight Struggle" ist auf den ersten Blick kompliziert. Und das ist es zugegebenermaßen erstmal durchaus auch. Nach ein paar rasch verlorenen Spielen kommt man aber gut rein und begreift die Mechaniken rasch, denn diese sind alle sinnvoll und logisch durchdacht. Wenn man die Regeln einmal kapiert hat, hat man sie auch drauf.

Das Spiel spricht sicher nur eine kleine Gruppe an, ist ein Nischen-Titel. Aber gerade das spricht für diese digitale Version, denn manche werden im real life nur schwer einen Spielpartner finden. Hier hat man die richtig gute KI oder online meist wirklich fordernde Gegner.

Technisch ist die Umsetzung sehr sauber gemacht, übersichtlich und gut bespielbar. Einige nette Sounds und kurze akustische Ausschnitte aus historischen Reden runden den durchweg guten Eindruck ab.

Wer mal in das Spiel hereinschauen mag, sollte sich das "Angespielt" Vorstellungs-Video des besten youtubers aller Zeiten für Strategiespiele "Steinwallen" anschauen. Die beste Einführung in dieses strategische Meisterwerk.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
10/10 Atmosphäre
10/10 Story
8/10 Grafik
7/10 Sound
10/10 Spielmechanik
10/10 Balancing
10/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Starke Umsetzung eines Meisterwerks der historischen Karten-Brettspiele.

[h1][b]10/10 Gesamtwertung

author: {'steamid': '76561198060338309', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 32040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27510, 'last_played': 1645166202}

author: {'steamid': '76561198158474621', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1704207773}
review:
以前我买过昆虫棋实体和STEAM版，只能精分或打AI玩。
终于我陆续买了TS的实体和STEAM版
发现精分没有打AI好玩。

author: {'steamid': '76561198249542564', 'num_games_owned': 1266, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1692841165}
review:
实体版有上十小时的游戏时间。这款电子版忠实还原了实体版，所以着重谈谈这款桌游。
至今最好的卡牌驱动（另一款MK也不错），常年霸占BGG第一的传奇桌游，BGG上备受歧视的美式桌游中的一朵奇葩。没玩过农场主、波多黎各、冷战热斗其中任何一款，是不配说自己是桌游geek的。游戏模拟了冷战时期两个超级大国的在世界地图上的博弈。说的粗俗一点，这其实是个把妹游戏。高复帅美帝，和穷小子肌肉男苏联，变着花样比赛追求妹子（其他国家）。
游戏为什么排名这么高？就在于其精准的模拟了冷战时期两个超级大国的行为方式，和其他国家的被动地位。在这里所有事情不过是手中的一张牌，所谓的道德、伦常只是冰冷利益的虚伪外衣——大韩航空被苏联空军击落，269人遇难，你欣喜若狂，于是借机向苏联发难，挽救了东亚岌岌可危的外交局势。你也可以封杀媒体，压住这张王牌不放，待到手中王牌够多，再打一套组合拳，彻底摧毁苏联在远东的影响力。
核倒计时、太空竞赛、巴以冲突、支持非洲独裁军阀、奥运赛场上明争暗斗。在这款游戏里，你和对手从非洲斗到亚洲，从体育斗到太空，没有宣战，但你死我活的暗中斗争却有一种诡异的、不输二战的残忍气氛。另外算分策略也设计得很巧妙——你并不知道对手要在哪里结算分数，但是，嘿！他在中东发力了，那就在中东干他丫的！这种莫名其妙的突然在某个地区互撕的行为方式，正是冷战所表现出的特征。
游戏也不是完全的平衡。美国前期弱，后期强。苏联反之。美帝要顶住前期巨大的红色压力，避免崩盘的惨剧，耐心等待后期翻盘。而苏联需要思考的是，如何用前期优势，顶住后期各国的颜色革命。这种卡牌设计，也精妙的还原了冷战的总体趋势。总的来说苏联赢面大点。

游戏规则比较复杂，没法再深入说的太细节。如果你对冷战感兴趣，又喜欢复杂的游戏，同时有个跟你一样奇怪口味的好友，这款游戏还是很推荐的。另外买之前建议先学规则，网上有很多视频和pdf，避免买了学不会的尴尬境地。另外欢迎大家找我切磋，我主要都是带教学，真玩起来也很菜（甚至输给过第一次玩、还在教学的新手）。

最后，一旦习惯了冷战热斗的行为方式，再去看台湾问题，就会对对岸同胞抱有深深的同情——你要真信了美帝“保障自由”的承诺，只能说你Naive。

author: {'steamid': '76561197972319866', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 909, 'last_played': 1682223395}
review:
An amazing board game that combines strategy and chance. It is built in such a way that even 30 games in you'll be amazed at how different action rounds take place. Many times you'll think you are being clever with your hand and your opponent, human or AI, will flip that notion on your head. However, you'll keep getting craftier and better as time goes on until you have to start giving the AI the handicap.

My number one warning is that this game can be incredibly addicting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028649652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 1200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1561749506}
review: A very good port of a great boardgame. There is no excuse for you to not have this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040175948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1063, 'last_played': 1710797025}
review: Great port of the board game, i highly suggest it for people interested as its cheaper than a physical copy and a lot easier play. Really helped me understand the rules of the board game version (i have both).

author: {'steamid': '76561198031384864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1599932820}
review: Twilight struggle is one of the best two player board games out there and this video game captures it perfectly. The perfect simplicity and transparancy of board game rules mixed with the smoothness and ease of not having to move pieces around. It is also great for anyone wanting to learn Twilight Struggle because the game doesn't let you break the rules/forget parts.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991872194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 4608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1020, 'last_played': 1703713024}
review: Fantastic port of a one of the best board games I have played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198366850270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 2330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1659922785}
review:
i love cold war history and games and this is the answer to my cravings.
a game that constantly makes you go "pffft i dont even know if i have the upper hand...whats the other guy going to do....?"
it feels like your constantly not winning. but you must be paitent.

also the rules a complicated. but once you get your head around it its pretty simple and straight foward.

theres only one thing i dont like about this game.
The A.I. for single player is BRUTAL. it shows no mercy. im not joking you have better odds of winning online.
and i swear it knows what i have planned or what im attempting to do. no matter which team i pick. i have not ever won a single player offline game. not even the tutorial.
your better off going up against people online, i only wish there was some kind of difficulty option for single player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198282102029', 'num_games_owned': 569, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1527481455}
review: 非常棒的桌游 我们需要中文。

author: {'steamid': '76561198015034287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1490781796}
review:
As a note beforehand, Twilight Struggle is one of the highest ranked board games on boardgamegeek since years (#1 or #2, I think). But I haven't played it yet.

The PC version looks very good and has nice music and sound. User interface is good, no bugs were encountered.

However, the AI seems to be not strong enough. I played the tutorial and then won both of my games, one with the US and one with USSR. So now I am not so motivated to play any more, altough there are the additional cards and the DLC promo cards.

Since the price is alright, I would give the game a ~. It would be a clear + if you want the game in order to play online with others. But since the AI is apparently no challenge anymore, it is a - for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077834093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 1689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1594, 'last_played': 1678784433}
review:
Jedna z nejlepších her převedená do digitální podoby. Určitě usnadňuje díky naprogramovanému vedení pochopení pro začátečníky. Hra hlídá veškeré kroky a nedovolí vám nějaký náhodou přeskočit. Pokud ještě máte kámoše, který je stejný hardocerový hráč, tak se může Twilight Struggle proměnit v několik skvěle strávených hodin plných triskajících emocí, kdy se z pozice lídra můžete propadnout až do jaderné války. Rozhodně doporučuji. 

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198126499212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 84139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 32, 'playtime_at_review': 33303, 'last_played': 1711977954}
review: 赖逼电脑筛子绝对作弊，AI不行强制让点不就得了，用这样恶心玩家吗？

author: {'steamid': '76561197991155047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 17960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1654224455}
review:
Twilight Struggle is one of my favorite games. I have a long history with playing this game on other online services with Vassal or Warroom. A good game between two skilled opponents is tense all the way to the end and the balance can be shifted through good card hand-management, anticipation of your opponents moves, and a little bit of luck with the dice.

The AI opponent is not skilled. It's not completely ludicrous in its behavior, but it does not consistently make the most optimal move by any stretch of the imagination. I have watched the AI headline Indo-Pakistani War when neither country has influence in either of those countries, for example. I have watched the AI, as the US, play the Blockade card with no discard and continuously throw their influence in W. Germany away for no good reason. These are things that can happen, to be sure, and could be the most optimum play under certain circumstances... but when the AI does these moves regularly, it is clear there could still be a little perfecting to be done in terms of the AI's computational skill. There is no setting the AI behavior to "easy, normal, hard" difficulty. It plays the same way every time. The only thing you can do to affect the difficulty is grant more influence to a side at start-up. You can choose to play a randomized side, or play with the Chinese Civil War or Late-War Start variants, though.

A complete beginner on the other hand would likely find the AI a worthy opponent and quite challenging. The problem is that the game is not all that intuitive to a complete beginner. Given Vassal and Warroom use the game board as it appears on the actual board game, I was surprised to see that the PC game does not use it, really. It compartmentalizes all of the information so you need to click on parts of the screen to really see how many military ops have been gained, what turn it is, what action round it is, where is everyone on the space race, etc. etc.  The one really nice thing about Twilight Struggle as a board game is you can just glance at the board and instantly see the entire situation. You don't have to just remember who's done what as you go along. The PC game decided to clean all of that up by hiding the detailed information in clickable menus and asides. In some cases, this is very good. It's very nice to see an icon and hold the mouse cursor over it to see a tool-tip that reminds you NORAD is in effect. On the other hand, it's inconvenient because one thing you really need to keep in mind is how many Mil. Ops. both sides have in the turn, and it's easy to forget when that info is hidden under a compartmentalized tab.

That said, the game does look very polished. There are, for example, recordings of quotes said by each historical figure when that figure's image appears. The DEFCON makes little warning klaxon noises when it lowers. (Thankfully not enough to become annoying.) The cards are easy to read with a nice big font. A lot of love went into this game. If anything I'd almost say it's too well polished. It looks so nice it can be distracting from the info the player needs to take into account when they're actually playing... going back to the compartmentalized information I mentioned before. It's certainly much nicer than Vassal or Warroom, but I feel like functionability went down by the tiniest smidgen as a result. I wish there was an option to just make the screen look like the actual board game.

That said, I would recommend it if you've played the game before. The AI might make silly moves at times, but it's not completely incompetent and it's a nice little time waster when you don't feel like taking on a human opponent. I haven't tested the online play yet, but assuming it's just as functional, there shouldn't be any problems there. If you have maybe seen the game once or twice and played it and felt frustrated because you didn't know what to do, then playing this game is certainly a good way to learn.

In the end, Twilight Struggle is still Twilight Struggle. The best board-game ever created. The PC copy is actually at least two times cheaper than buying the physical copy, and a thousand times easier to clean up. Recommended, even if one could wish the AI was a little more adept.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016125904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 17356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9444, 'last_played': 1697790826}
review: I absolutely adore this game. It is difficult. You have to think about each move very carefully. One slip up and its all over. But mastering this game is part of the fun and intrigue. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064146597', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1698922304}

author: {'steamid': '76561198192993177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1568170915}
review:
手游界的《文明5》——特别消磨时间，一局最长可以打两个小时甚至以上，不过就游戏内容和游戏题材来说确实是手游界中难得的。
另外希望能出中文版，如果说有国人自制的汉化补丁也不错，现在我就是凭借着自己英文水平和以前的记忆来打……（我以前玩过这个系列的实体卡牌）

author: {'steamid': '76561198040923434', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 11357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1550858751}
review:
The dev is full of shit (or just insane, whatever), the game overheats laptops trying to render at 2000FPS what is a static 2D world map, the soundscape is hilariously bad...


But it's the nicest GUI, it is reasonnably bug-free, and it works very well online.


PS: also might be one of the best wargames of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961626011', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 13174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2941, 'last_played': 1708395071}
review: I just started playing the board game version with a buddy and wanted something to allow me to 'get up to speed' with him. Suffice to say, 10 hours later I feel a lot more comfortable taking him on now. The computer AI isn't great but was perfect for practicing against. Since the online portion is through Playdek I'm hoping we can play cross platform.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097918182', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1658337197}
review: 作为一个实体版的伪老司机，在听说要发PC版的时候就很期待。然而发售到现在都那么多了，还是等不到任何多语言的消息。而作为硬核桌游，在国内十分小众，也没有大神来做外挂的汉化。虽然说玩久了基本都认识，但是还是希望看中文方便啊。而且就是因为语言问题，想拉很多小伙伴来他们都说看不懂不愿意玩。实际上游戏是十分有趣的，玩的时候双方很平静，实际上内心各种惊涛骇浪。

author: {'steamid': '76561197967141830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 34001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3277, 'last_played': 1586451704}
review:
Great computer adaptation to an amazing board game. I will admit to learning some of the rule nuances while playing (notably the fact that ending the game via nuclear war is a valid strategy). The AI is fairly strong, which is a refreshing change from most board game adaptations that I've played (decent Axis and Allies anyone??). 

**Note: I changed my review based on further research into the rules and further gameplay (Charlie.pag, I couldn't agree more with your earlier comment)

author: {'steamid': '76561197988448157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1496964245}
review: Llevo perdidas tres partidas y empezadas unas 10, no he ganado ninguna pero llevo un vicio monumental. Está en ingles y es nivel meio-facil, te puedes mirar algun tutorial en español de gente jugando al de tablero pq es exactamente igual. Hay que tener paciencia pq al principio parece dificil pero luego no lo es tanto. Vicio asegurado, ahora me planteo comprarme el de tablero.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097683248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1489967772}
review: The Game itself is decent, but this version is horrible.  The game is heavily  pitted against you, so winning is impossible. Most of the times, you will lose any coups. Most of the times, the computer not only just wins, but destroys you so bad that the game is over before it starts. The game needs better instructions to help learn the game. The game is overall infuriating when you will never win. The computer will most likely beat you by turn 4 or 5.  They need something to help teach strategy to the game, and need difficulty settings. I'm using full handicap mode, with 10 extra  influence points to set the board up, and the PC just kills it all by the end of turn 2 until you are overwhelmed and have no hope. Then it deals you with all USSR cards if you are the US, and so you screwing yourself  with any decision your make. The fustration just makes this game unplayable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995707284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 11131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6475, 'last_played': 1706663846}
review:
Wow, what a great game to stumble upon.  Not often that you find a game that is so well done that  I can't think of anything bad to say.  Well, the AI sometimes does some dumb stuff, and it takes a little longer to make it's turn than I think it should, but really what game out there (besides chess) has great AI?

Like chess, it takes some time to get good - the computer thrashed me in the beginning, but I've gotten to where I can beat it pretty regular now.

MP works well, but since you are relying on someone else, your mileage may vary.  I've played about 5 games and a couple of opponents just quit, but I've had 2 really good games to balance it out.

I recommend you check out a few websites on the game to really learn what's going on.  I had some issues in the beginning, especially with defcon suicides.

5 star all day long.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262486912', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1617314531}
review:
[spoiler] 不管怎么说总归比实体版便宜多了不是么	[/spoiler]
当然能够网上对战也很不错，不过不推荐新手一上来就找虐
现在没有中文，所以英文不好的话一开始会比较吃力，基本上2-3局人机对战（4h上下）才能够大体了解所有的卡牌
在这之后请直接在网上搜索一下卡牌分析及攻略以期对TS有一个比较全面的了解
当然把TS当作了解冷战地缘的一个工具也是很不错的

author: {'steamid': '76561197972271226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 6218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2683, 'last_played': 1711197601}
review: A slick, easy-to-use, faithful representation of the highly-rated board game. Nothing to complain about.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064822383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2198, 'last_played': 1685558928}
review: Twilight Struggle is considered the best boardgame ever. This is its faithful transposition on PC. Play some matches in the single player mode, then start enjoy the competitive multiplayer (matches are ranked as ELO system in chess). Bonus: PC version is crossed with mobile versions. I have both and it is very confortable to switch from a platform to another.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124158373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 17611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8587, 'last_played': 1696544316}
review:
Boardgame sitelerinde tüm dünyada en çok tutulan oyunlardan biri olan Twilight struggle adlı boardgame oyununun bilgisayar versiyonu. İki kişi ile oynanan, birazcık şans işin içinde olsa da ciddi stratejik düşünme gerektiren bir oyun. Soğuk savaş zamanında, Amerika yada Rusya olarak dünyayı ele geçirmeye çalışıyorsunuz. Oyunun içindeki kartlar tamamen gerçek olaylardan esinlenerek hazırlanmış.   

Bana sorarsanız masaüstü versiyonundan daha iyi olmuş. Türkçesi olmaması nedeniyle tam olarak anlaşılamayan bazı kuralları bu steam versiyonunda daha rahat anlıyorsunuz. Türkiyede oyuncu çok olmaması ve bir araya gelmenin zor olması nedeniyle oyunu çok sevmeme rağmen oynayacak rakip bulmakta çok zorlanıyordum. Şimdi dünyanın dört bir yanından insanlarla istediğim kadar oynayabiliyorum. Ama dikkat kendinizi çok kaptırırsanız insanın hayatını gerçekten kötü etkiliyor, bu oyun yüzünden doktora tezimi 6 ay geç yazdım desem yeridir. :) 

Son söz olarak, board game oyunlarını ve strateji yapmayı seven biriyseniz kaçırmayın derim.
